awd_titl_txt: RII Track-4: Dynamic Live Imaging and Manipulation of Migrating Collectives Inside Tissues
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Description:
During the development of embryos, groups of cells (referred to as 'collectives') move together to help form tissues and organs. Movement of these collectives inside the developing embryo is poorly understood. This fellowship will study development of the fruit fly as a model system to understand how cell collectives move within, and interact with, living, intact tissues. The scientific goals of this project are to use new advanced microscopic methods to reveal how collectives move in tissues, and to use light to control cell movements. The PI and a postdoctoral fellow will be trained in these new techniques at the University of California, Santa Barbara, and will then bring the techniques back to the home institution (Kansas State University). These studies will result in new tools that can be used to study how embryos develop into fully formed animals, and to improve our broader understanding of how cell collectives move within tissues.

Technical Description
The migration of multicellular groups, or cell collectives, is vital to the formation and reorganization of tissues during organogenesis. While collective migrations are required for development, it is not well understood how cells stay ordered and migratory despite moving inside densely packed tissues. Drosophila border cells are an excellent genetically tractable model system to address how cell collectives physically and molecularly interact with the native tissue environment. The goal of this fellowship is to uncover mechanisms that underlie interactions between migrating collectives and tissues through the use of cutting-edge live cell imaging of the border cell system. The work will be performed in partnership with reasearchers at the University of California, Santa Barbara, which is a leader in the field of collective cell migration and innovative live cell manipulation and imaging. The PI will employ a combination of Selective Plane Illumination (SPIM) light sheet fluorescent microscopy (LSFM), in vivo biosensors, and optogenetic tools that employ light to manipulate protein function in live cells, will be used at the host site. These techniques will address: (1) how tissue shape and organization impacts border cell collective migration; and (2) how Rap1, a key signaling protein, controls the adhesion strength and dynamics of border cells during their migration inside the tissue. The project will allow the PI to create and use innovative imaging and optogenetic tools to considerably advance our conceptual and mechanistic understanding of how cell collectives migrate in complex native environments. The PI will introduce and promote adoption of this technology at the PI?s home institution, Kansas State University (KSU) by training other investigators on how to use biosensors and optogenetic tools.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The migration of groups of cells, or "collectives", is vital to the development of animals from embryo to adult. Such collective cell movements help form and remodel tissues and organs. An open question is how cells in collectives stay ordered and migratory despite moving inside densely packed tissues. The goal of this EPSCoR Track 4 proposal was to use new and existing live cell imaging tools to address the cellular and molecular features that help cell collectives move inside tissues. This project specifically used the Drosophila melanogaster (common fruit fly) border cells as a model system to image and manipulate cell collectives in vivo. The training was performed at the University of California, Santa Barbara with Dr. Denise Montell, a leader in collective cell migration and innovative in vivo live cell imaging. A combination of Selective Plane Illumination (SPIM) light sheet fluorescent microscopy (LSFM), in vivo biosensors and new tools to "optogenetically" manipulate protein function were used at the host site to address: 1) how tissue shape and organization impacts border cell collective migration; and 2) how and when the small GTPase Rap1, a key signaling protein, controls border cells during migration in the tissue.

This training opportunity helped the principal investigator (PI) and her team learn sophisticated imaging techniques to visualize and manipulate the migrating border cell collective. Specifically, using the expertise of the host lab, the PI and trainee learned how to perform two-color confocal imaging of live border cell migration, how to better quantify in vivo cellular behaviors, and how to perform photo-activation of existing optogenetic tools to manipulate protein activity in live border cells. Further, the PI learned how to mount and image samples on a commercial LSFM at the host site, a technology that is unavailable in the state of Kansas. The PI and trainee worked with the host lab to design, and re-design, optogenetic tools and a biosensor to manipulate and visualize Rap1 activity, respectively. This project successfully implemented the new tools, including troubleshooting, and has provided a framework to further improve both the biosensor and optogenetic tools.

The project resulted in training of the PI and a postdoctoral researcher at the host site, training a graduate student at the home institution in imaging methods we learned, and training an undergraduate student from an historically underrepresented group at the home institution. Two peer-reviewed manuscripts (one published and one in revision), four conference presentations, and an in-press methods book chapter directly stemmed from this project. Several imaging-focused outreach activities allowed us to bring imaging to the broader community, including a local Science Caf? talk on ?The amazing green fluorescent protein (GFP): from jellyfish to breakthrough discoveries?, a local outreach activity on GFP to 9th-12th grade girls interested in science, and fluorescent microscope image awards to the postdoctoral researcher at the regional, national, and international levels. The expertise learned by the PI and trainees is expected to continue to be disseminated to strengthen science and competitiveness of the institution and the state.


Last Modified: 11/27/2022
Modified by: Jocelyn Mcdonald
